Grant Description: The Question Formulation Technique (QFT) allows students to develop divergent, convergent and metacognitive thinking abilities in a short period of time. QFT offers teachers a subtle, but transformational shift in pedagogy that helps their students learn to produce their own questions, improve their questions and strategize on how to use them. This grant will fund several experiments on how best to introduce the QFT, support its use and document its impact in a range of New England school districts.

Grant Recipient Name: Close to Home Domestic Violence Prevention Initiative
Grant Population Served: Children and youth; LGBTQ people; Women and girls; Ethnic and racial groups; Economically disadvantaged people; Victims of crime and abuse; People with disabilities
Grant Description: "Founded in 2002, Close to Home has spent the past 12 years creating and implementing innovative models to mobilize communities to end domestic and sexual violence. After a recently completed organizational development and reflection process, Close to Home’s leadership has come to the conclusion that it can no longer sustain its programs within the organization’s current infrastructure. As a result, Close to Home has decided to close down the organization and transition its programs to a network of organizations that will continue to grow and develop its work to engage communities in ending violence. A $100K tie-off grant from the NoVo Foundation will support C2H’s transition process, which will begin in June 2014. C2H will leverage NoVo’s funds to document and share key learnings, models, and tools with the broader movement to end domestic and sexual violence and ensure that its programs thrive in their new organizational homes."

Grant Description: Promoting health and wellness in Boston's Latino and Mission Hill/Roxbury communities is a key piece of our mission and has been a central part of our work for nearly 40 years. As a Latino organization with deep roots in the local community, Sociedad Latina implements health and wellness programming informed by a racial/ethnic equity lens and with a high level of cultural relevance. We have been recognized by the world-renowned hospitals of Longwood Medical Area, the National Council of La Raza and countless other organizations as the standard-bearer for developing effective programs that produce positive outcomes for Latino youth and their families. Our health programming draws on a wide range of cross-sector partners to ensure quality and success, including the five hospitals of Boston's Longwood Medical Area, Whittier Street Health Center, the Family Van, the National Council of La Raza's Institute for Hispanic Health and more.

That integrated learning environment is then extended over the summer by having students in our Math*sTARS programs participate in our Algebra Plus Summer Academy. Grant Description: LGR is the only organization that uses college-students to provide under-represented and low-income students with free SAT prep, assistance with the college application process, college visits, and mentoring all in one program. And LGR?S programs are deeply embedded in the community ? Partnering closely with high schools, colleges and community organizations. Let?S Get Ready?S near-peer model, consists of rigorous SAT preparation, College choice curriculum, and college trips. LGR also provides college transition and success services to help students be successful throughout college. The grant will be used to support our New England based students being served through our college access, transition and success programs.

Underserved youth, grades K-8 study math and literacy; enhancing the growth of their academic skills with hands on projects and intensive enrichments including science, robotics, art, theatre and physical education. The summer program takes place at school-based sites for five weeks, Monday through Friday for 6.5 hours per day. Additionally, BELL provides e-learning and classroom-based training for teachers and tutors; education workshops; special events; and other resources to families to strengthen students' learning and support

Grant Description: For JMSCHC's Eliminating Health Disparities Program, which aims to continue to reduce health disparities and improve health outcomes by increasing access to care among vulnerable and isolated populations in Allston/Brighton and Waltham through health literacy education, preventative screenings, and insurance enrollment assistance. The program has successfully targeted underserved populations that face socio-economic and linguistic to barriers to care, including low income families, cultural and racial minorities, unemployed individuals, recent immigrants, and those with low English proficiency. Community Health Workers enhance health literacy by conducting street outreach and facilitating community members into care while Health Benefits Counselors help patients identify public insurance programs for which they are eligible, gather the required documentation required, enroll in appropriate programs, and follow up in case of denials
